name: er
content:
er

exclamation
 
/ɜː(r)/
 
/ɜːr/
(also erm)
(British English)
jump to other results
  1. the sound that people make when they are deciding what to say next
    • ‘Will you do it?’ ‘Er, yes, I suppose so.’
    • I’m, er, I’m going now.

name: ER
content:
ER

abbreviation
 
/ˌiː ˈɑː(r)/
 
/ˌiː ˈɑːr/
(North American English)
jump to other results
  1. ​emergency room (= the part of a hospital where people who need immediate treatment are taken)
    CultureER is also the name of a US television medical series that ran between 1994 and 2009. The programme was set in a Chicago teaching hospital. It won 22 Emmy awards, as well as the People's Choice Award for 'Favorite TV Dramatic Series' every year from 1995 to 2002.
See ER in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ER

name: erbium
content:
erbium

noun
 
/ˈɜːbiəm/
 
/ˈɜːrbiəm/
[uncountable]
(symbol Er)
jump to other results
  1. ​a chemical element. Erbium is a soft silver-white metal.
    Word Originmid 19th cent.: modern Latin, from (Ytt)erb(y), in Sweden, where it was first found. Compare with ytterbium.
See erbium in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: erm
content:
erm

exclamation
 
/ɜːm/
 
/ɜːrm/
(also er)
(British English)
jump to other results
  1. ​the sound that people make when they are deciding what to say next
    • ‘Shall we go?’ ‘Erm, yes, let's.’
Check pronunciation: erm

name: -er
content:
-er

suffix
 
/ə(r)/
 
/ər/
jump to other results
  1. ​(in nouns) a person or thing that performs the action
    • lover
    • computer
    compare -ee, -or
  2. ​(in nouns) a person or thing that has the thing or quality mentioned
    • three-wheeler
    • foreigner
  3. ​(in nouns) a person studying or expert in
    • astronomer
    • philosopher
  4. ​(in nouns) a person belonging to
    • New Yorker
  5. ​(makes comparative adjectives and adverbs)
    • wider
    • bigger
    • happier
    • sooner
    compare -est
    More Like This SuffixesSuffixes

name: Gen Xer
content:
Gen Xer

noun
 
/ˌdʒen ˈeksə(r)/
 
/ˌdʒen ˈeksər/
(also Gen X-er)
(also Generation Xer)
(informal)
jump to other results
  1. ​a person who was born between the middle of the 1960s and the late 1970s, which makes them a member of Generation X
    • 1 in 3 Gen Xers said they were most concerned about saving enough for retirement.
    compare Gen Yer, Gen ZerTopics People in societyc2
Check pronunciation: Gen Xer
